In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation establishing standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we have had to create new spaces to combat the rapid and growing traffic in children.
The authorization of passports for children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental step in winning this difficult and important battle.

In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children as young as six is already a practice with a long tradition, which, perhaps for this reason, does not raise any objections from me.
As an advocate for the European cause, I believe that in this matter, harmonization is important.

It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long set the minimum age at six years old for the collection of fingerprints, will not have to change their national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of the passports this system enhances does not end with the mere existence of a passport.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in security levels, ranging from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control points.

end of quote

We all know perfectly well that in a situation of a pandemic of influenza, it is the countries of the South that have suffered the most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the countries of the North.

We have no limits for this list and we passively witness this problem.

We effectively use Southern countries as free title suppliers, providing samples and new virus strains to improve treatment in Northern countries. However, we lack effective responses to these issues. Therefore, in addition to the questions raised, I would like to add a few more.

On the other hand, I would like to ask, and hope it is not the case, whether we are expecting that, after all, the vaccine appointments in Europe become so overloaded.
The secondary effects prove to be so negative in this plan, for that reason, in an act of generosity, we suddenly start sending necessary vaccines to the countries of the south.

member countries, the painful nature of decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union among citizens and in the eyes of the world.

Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is immense. The financial system, which was supposed to serve them, has destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.

With regard to the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, including banking, insurance, and securities, the way forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing here today.
In fact, we need a strong European supervisory architecture that covers all products of actors, which is equipped with methodologies and instruments
effective interventions and be able to respond to the reality of the market, which, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spills over into the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms in place that limit contagion, especially regarding the banking system, as it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the custodian of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely within the powers and competencies of the banking authority, lies the ability to implement a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, the subject to which my report refers.
It is not within our power to prevent bank failures, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is carried out in a manner that
In an organized manner, limiting collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they create.

For this, a set of new tools is required. It is necessary to adopt common rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology for all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, particularly bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors extended powers of intervention.
It is necessary to develop clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that enable interventions to be initiated in a struggling institution.
It is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
This entire process for twenty-seven member states takes time.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the planet's main environmental and social problems. Each year, we lose 13 million hectares of forest, contributing to 20% of global carbon emissions and posing a massive threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is incalculable and, as such, is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
The loss of floral diversity puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not evenly distributed among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that most depend on forests and nature for their survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our collective existence, to the depletion of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and to social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20% to 40% of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing a transfer of wealth from producer countries to consumer countries of the same timber.
This illegal practice endangers the sustainable exploitation of timber and the businesses that engage in it.
Mere words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions alone are not enough.
Means and measures are necessary, namely sanctions that, in this case, may be of three types.

Firstly, measures that effectively remove the economic benefit from illegal practices exacerbated by recidivism, secondly, the confiscation of wood from the products in question, and thirdly, the immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out commercial activities.

And so, it is because those who exploit or commercialize a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also that those who first introduce wood into wood products in the European Union must be required to take due diligence to ensure that it is legally harvested wood.
That is why all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this wood, namely its provenance and its destination.
The population should also have the right, and I finish here, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not comply. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the goal of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities between the various regions.
It is not enough to express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions within the Union that face permanent constraints which significantly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that effectively and realistically overcome the delay of these regions by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.

Incentives for these regions should stem not only from regional policy measures through its structural instruments, such as the cohesion policy and the four structural funds, but also from other sources.
also from a different use of the various sectoral policies that have a significant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a dynamizing effect on their economies.
For the determination of European aid for these regions, it is certain that we must maintain GDP as the main eligibility indicator.

However, and taking into account its natural disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria that can provide a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more comprehensive portrait of the complex reality of the most privileged regions.

Recall, in this regard, the case of the outermost regions, whose status was recognized by the new Treaty. These are a group of regions within the European Union that possess specific characteristics and also warrant special treatment.
The regions of the ultra-periphery, united due to their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Additionally, concerning these countries, complementary GDP indicators should be employed, which can provide a more comprehensive description of their specific realities and thus contribute to a more precise determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.

Today, more than ever, achieving economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.

This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that it is only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension that we can have a Europe that is cohesive internally and competitive externally.

In this particular context, I would emphasize three crucial points: firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more actively and contribute to the better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member States should invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives, and finally, enhance the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management, and implementation of programs.

Another aspect I deem crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.

That, contrary to what sometimes appears to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Deception is a false promise, as I would like to call it, because we have been operating, especially in the collection of stem cells, umbilical cord nuclei, based on misleading information.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases may be inexhaustible, diseases such as those that have already been refractory to cancer, like Alzheimer's disease, and rare diseasesâthe possibilities are immense.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a network of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells, and from then on, at the time of birth and onwards, cure them in the future if necessary.
I believe we should be more responsible than that, because the likelihood of ensuring it happens is very low, as we know.

The first factor relates to the fact that some producers and consumers of foods, which were previously exporters, have become importers, as is the case with China.
This has nothing to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinationals can make prices be judged in their favor.
The example of the cereal industry is very clear at this level, dominated by six large multinational corporations.
This situation thus places farmers in a state of great uncertainty regarding food product prices.

First and foremost, one must ask why review VAT in the European Union?

A reform of VAT favors e-commerce, focuses competition on the value of goods and the base price of goods and services, rather than on tax differentials.

Firstly, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism for the single market.
Measure five, concerning services, highlights the need to revise legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive.
The new measure aims to remove tax obstacles and explicitly revise the VAT system, and to equalize VAT in online and face-to-face trade, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two fundamental orders of reasons.
Firstly, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, in some countries, likely a reduction in labor contributions to promote economic development, shifting this burden to VAT.
Secondly, the second major source of pressures is the aging population, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxation, due to the reduction in the tax base population.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, in these reforms, we have to reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the range of variation in the standard VAT rate so that we can all understand better.
There is a need for greater transparency in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, along with a clear and widely disseminated list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for MSPs, fully aware that each exemption brings with it a train of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, to welcome the commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.

Important in the realm of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are highly evident and have been outlined above. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with simple consultation of the electronic platform, thereby reducing many costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

Small and medium-sized enterprises, online advertising, and the ease of accessing procedural documents increase the number of suppliers, heighten competition, and enable better purchasing, thus making the process of awarding public contracts more efficient.

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thus facilitating their participation in the market, and the access of these important economic drivers to public procurement.
In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission's efforts to strengthen mechanisms to make electronic public procurement an increasingly widespread reality. Thank you.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And while the situation has quickly shifted from being perceived as a Greek or Portuguese problem to a major European-wide issue, the truth is that the inadequacy and delay of the proposed solutions have resulted in no effectiveness, only contributing to the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions tailored for individual states at the expense of truly European solutions enabled markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and imposing deadlines and timelines.
It is absolutely impossible for some states to achieve their goals through measures of unimaginable anti-Chinese brutality imposed on individuals, businesses, and the public sector.

It is absolutely imperative to find a common solution, already identified for the risk of supranational debts, which alleviates pressure from speculative markets and provides time for what is essential to be accomplished.
Without it, what we will have at the end are countries that will continue without means to pay creditors, destroyed economies, and much suffering.

to the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I would also like to thank the rapporteurs from the partners of the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 4 out of 7 compromises, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by the topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, in fact, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy in drafting the report was to rephrase common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that this goal has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the fragilities of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the past's achievements.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has lost more than five million jobs.
Today, nearly twenty-three million people are employed.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and represents more than double the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all member states, unemployment rates vary according to qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find employment more easily.
We also know that, in the near future, the needs in terms of skills, competencies, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of professions.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and maintain competitiveness.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding individuals with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.
This report thus has a dual objective: firstly, to emphasize the need to act swiftly to address skills gaps in Europe; secondly, to better anticipate the skills needs of the labor market.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. Firstly, to ensure the availability of a qualified workforce, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as competencies in science and innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As already mentioned, skill requirements should be identified early on, with a minimum perspective of ten years.
Today, we understand the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Subsequently, there should be an increase in participation in lifelong learning and vocational retraining, as well as in reducing school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that should exist between educational institutions and the demands of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors to ensure they lead to employment opportunities and prevent any potential exploitation of interns.
Special emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have the future ahead of us and we must create jobs.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role here for this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, and hence the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, in particular, the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labor market flexibility. To enhance the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexicurity should be tailored to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Many thanks.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, and colleagues. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Arden, on the quality and timeliness of this report, as well as Commissioner Andor on the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and swift action to stem the rise of a phenomenon that normally affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The severe crisis we are going through has exacerbated this situation and made the times we live in dramatic, as your Commissioner Andor stated.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that joblessness is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.

Therefore, I warmly welcome the initiative of the fight against Poverty, which is a very important instrument to ensure social justice.

We have been taking medication for three years to get out of the crisis, and the situation is worsening day by day.
In place of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first between banks and the state.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a major bank, but we continue to assume that banks finance states and that states save their banks.
This spiral needs to be broken.
The mission must move forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from banking crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of the States and shield it from speculators' attacks.

For this, it is urgent and long overdue to prepare coordinated emissions of a sovereign nature, whether called Good or Stability Bonds, and guarantee them through robust community-based and non-intergovernmental instruments.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle arises from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically incorrect.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and currency, constructed through political choice among unequals, necessarily exacerbate competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what needs to be anchored in economic governance.
It is not imposed through sanctions and does not promote the crushing of wages and incomes through the control of one country over another.

Previously, through a commitment from the Commissioner, I would like to see countries with surpluses engage with those countries with deficits in order to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The tensions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and something else.

Thank you, Mr. President, I believe we are at a time for taking stock of these crisis policies and austerity measures that have affected so many countries, as well as the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social unrest not only in countries facing the greatest difficulties, in countries in pain, not just in so-called PIIGS, but also in other contexts within Europe.
Moreover, last week Portugal witnessed its largest general strike ever, encompassing both the public and private sectors. This was a strike that took to the streets.
But, if we look at people in the United Kingdom, we find that we are witnessing the largest strike ever, especially considering that people also took to the streets, as they did in Portugal.
We expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, President, and what the strikes prove and the people taking to the streets demonstrates, is that the causes and problems we have been facing are shared, and that is why the reaction is also shared.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We witnessed the chaos in financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are otherwise healthy, leading others to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the rigorous need for budgetary discipline, deep restructurings, and enhanced economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will precipitate itself.
Therefore, now more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need a strong and confident intervention from the European Central Bank.

Mr. President, I begin by congratulating my colleague on the excellent work and noting the coincidence that, on Europe Day, which we celebrate today, we are both debating and approving measures tomorrow that respond to the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

What this regulation aims to address is the imposition of limits on mobile phone charges levied on European consumers when roaming. Its ultimate objective is to eliminate roaming fees within the European area by 2016.
Our citizens now benefit from a significant price reduction for calls to GSMMS and data services.
If nowadays there are operators that charge three euros per mega, from July the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, dropping to 20 cents in 2014.
As for received calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: providing consumers with higher quality information.
Starting from the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices applied when they travel outside the European Union as well.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able to, if they so wish, have two contracts: one for services within the national territory and another for post-services abroad, while retaining the same mobile number and receiving only one bill.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be granted the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
in February 2009, this Parliament adopted a report in which it supported the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.

In my understanding, budgetary discipline means honoring contracts with pensioners and not abandoning state commitments halfway. In my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or subsidy cuts.

The fundamental aspect is to honor commitments in health, education, and culture, without closing services or halting and canceling projects midway. Discipline means putting the banks in order, not taking taxpayers' money to hand over to speculators to save their banks.

Balancing control and autonomy, and ensuring legitimacy at the national level, is not an easy task. It has devolved into a level of imposition, particularly of discipline, and ultimately may even lead to a serious package of sanctions.

With regard to the TuPE, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give its negotiators a negotiating mandate that is in line with the ambition to quickly finalize this package, the TuPE.

But more European coordination, returning to the theme, means less control by countries over their own destiny. What is required is a suboptimal balance, but it is also an increased demand for the quality of recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure consistency between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations focused primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be consistency.

With the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular, the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary for us to agree that there is a minimum linear set of social, economic, and labor rights that cannot be surpassed by these recommendations. Lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be measured based on the results achieved, although this is far from being the case so far.

It is true, and given that it has been discussed many times, that there are many things we do not know about the extraction of resources in this region.
But there are also many that we already know and it is advisable not to forget them.
We know, for instance, that each expense extraction operation uses over 9 million liters of drinking water, enough to supply a thousand European citizens for a year in terms of their needs.

We also know that with each extraction of dexto gas in each of the operations, 30 to 300 tons of chemical products are pumped into the ground, and up to 300 tons of chemicals can reach the soil, approximately 80% of which remain in the ground and do not leave it.

We also know that, with each gas extraction, X radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic residues resulting from the process, constitute the actual threat to public health.
This is a period of contamination of drinking water resources, and it is a real and imminent contamination.

Knowing this, we understand that the extraction of gas from this area is a response that is apparently easy, focusing only on the immediate, on industry and profit, while ignoring populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that understands, within this house, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect citizens' health and must do so, that seeks to make agreements to prevent emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, both environmental and health standards.
Therefore, when you don't know everything, being informed is the least you can do.
And they might want to do so, but do not do it in our name and in the name of citizens whom we represent here.
Colleagues, President, indeed, recent years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
We further demonstrated that we had a European institutional architecture riddled with bureaucracies, in particular, the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report presented here and the proposal put forward are on a much higher level in terms of the vision regarding what is proposed by the governments.

But also, as the rapporteur mentioned, we are in the realm of making political choices, and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some issues and will not be able to support this report.
The first has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to have as a narrative is that solidarity among different countries can only exist when everything is fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, the covenant for
more than one set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries, and also a set of reactive measures that, as we have seen, are not working.
The second reason pertains to the banking union.
The report very well presents the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot avoid the essential, and the essential is escaping us insofar as we continue to summarize.

clustered national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong, and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.
A third note concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
I will consider this possibility of issuing a common life again, but only when it is too late.

Because we need debt as it stands now, not only when deficits and excessive debts are corrected, because with the policies we are pursuing, they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of entire populations.

Therefore, Mr. President, I wish to conclude by saying that, despite all the odds, I believe we have a very clear example here that together we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to go even further.
Mrs. Ferreira, please note that there is always room for improvement, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union in recent years has been crucial.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness relied on cheap labor to a country with a highly skilled and sophisticated workforce.
But when the country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for where.
That is why it is important for some countries with surpluses to open their doors to requalified exports from countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to state that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, for the retrained workforce and those who benefited from European Union support to now be lost through a massive export of the most skilled to countries with the means to receive them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, small-scale fishing should receive particular protection from fisheries policies, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor that keeps these communities anchored along the coastal zones.
Its economic and social sustainability should be a goal, ensuring them a differentiated fisheries regime that prioritizes access to resources.
Allow the issue of proximity and protect the fishing rights known to the fishing professionals in these communities from transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for its sustainability to establish an access regime for waters, especially in waters or regions with biogeographic basins.
Navies with reduced continental shelves and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that should have protected access.

In the context of liberalization and the crisis affecting fragile regions, it is also necessary to ensure that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those imported by the Union.

a financial point, and the question that arises is the following: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to exacerbate the crisis?
Most European countries are today making a huge effort from the standpoint of their public finances to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries

If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in the cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge effort to modernize and develop will be severely penalized.
